newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - China, Thailand in the news.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - China, Thailand in the news.

text.p: Bank of China successfully re-entered international capital markets on Wednesday with its first issue in more than two years.
Meanwhile, bankers in Hong Kong said they expect Thailand to go forward with its Yankee bond this week despite receiving rating downgrades from Moody's Investors Service.
China's most influential state-owned commercial bank launched a US$300 million floating rate note due April 2004 that can be called at par after five years.
The notes pay a coupon of 37.5 basis points over the six-month London Interbank Offered Rate and were launched at 99.80 to give a discount margin of 41 basis points.
Fees are 35 basis points.
Morgan Stanley International and Bank of China International were joint lead managers.
The issue is rated Baa1 by Moody's Investors Service and a notch lower at BBB by Standard and Poor's Corp.
Moody's rates the sovereign at A3, while S&P assesses China at BBB.

Morgan Stanley said earlier this month that the issue would have a tenor of five or seven years. As recently as a few days ago, bankers were betting that Bank of China would opt for a straight five-year on views that there would be more demand in that maturity.
Bankers speculated that a five-year bond would pay a margin in the low 30s, a few basis points tighter than Construction Bank of China's recent US$200 million issue.
Construction Bank's five-year FRN paid a fixed-reoffer yield of 33 basis points and an all-in of 37.5 basis points.
But syndicate managers involved in the Bank of China deal said they had no problem selling the seven-year callable paper.
"The deal is paying about eight basis points more for the two-year extension and nobody can complain about that," said a syndicate manager at a European bank involved in the deal.
In addition to the two joint leads, 20 banks from the U.S., Europe and Asia joined in management roles.
Elsewhere, debt traders shrugged off news that Moody's Investors Service had downgraded Thailand's long-term foreign currency rating to A3 from A2.
"The spreads widened when Moody's put Thailand on negative watch so the downgrade was pretty much priced in," said a trader at a U.S. bank in Hong Kong.

Moody's also cut the senior debt and deposit ratings of five Thai banks to A3 from A2. The banks were Bangkok Bank, Export-Import Bank of Thailand, Industrial Finance Corp of Thailand, Siam Commercial Bank and Thai Farmers Bank.
Moody's affirmed the A3 subordinated debt ratings of Bangkok Bank, Siam Commercial Bank and Thai Farmers Bank.
Thailand's long-awaited Yankee bond still is expected to go forward later this week despite the Moody's move.
"Thailand surely has known for days that Moody's was going to announce the downgrade, so if they were going to postpone the issue they would have done it earlier," said one banker.
There is some speculation that the US$500 million bond will have a 10-year maturity and will be priced to yield around 90 basis points over Treasuries, but this is not confirmed.
Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers are leading the Thailand deal.
PTT Exploration and Production said it still planned to issue US$200 million in bonds overseas despite its downgrade to A3 by Moody's.
The Yankee bond for the central bank of the Philippines is expected to come hot on the heels of the Thailand issue. Salomon is the lead.

In other news, bankers said state-owned Land Bank of Taiwan may scupper its plan to issue US$100 in floating rate certificates of deposit because it is unhappy with the pricing offered by arranging banks.
